For more on this, we refer to any textbook on algebraic topology, e.g., the one by Hatcher [2]. 3.2.2 Boundary Maps Now that we can talk algebraically about sets of p-simplices, we can now formalize the notion of the boundary. It should be intuitively clear what the boundary of a single p-simplex should be: just take the (p−1)-chain formed by its facets. More formally, let σ = {v ,...,v } be a p-simplex.
